lens.lens_summary: The user stories analysis combined with Freud's theory of instinctual renunciation reveals the host journey as a negotiation between the individual's desire for privacy, control, and autonomy (instinctual freedom) and the platform's demand that hosts surrender personal space, accept strangers, and conform to marketplace rules (civilization's demands) — with every phase requiring a new act of renunciation that the platform must make economically and psychologically viable.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Discovery is the moment before renunciation begins — the host is still in a state of instinctual freedom regarding their space. Freud's Ch III identifies three sources of suffering: nature, the body, and human relationships. For hosts, the third source is the one that matters: the anxiety of inviting strangers into their private domain. The user stories document reveals that 'value before the ask — always' is the governing principle: hosts must see something useful before they give anything up. Freud explains why: any request for information or commitment before demonstrating value activates the pain of premature renunciation. The host has not yet agreed to civilize their private space. Asking them to register, fill forms, or declare intentions before showing value violates the pleasure principle — it imposes cost before any possibility of reward. The existing library (works-004) addresses the human-to-digital handoff, but this lens reveals a deeper layer: the host in discovery is not just evaluating a platform, they are unconsciously assessing whether this civilization (the marketplace) is worth the instinctual sacrifice it demands.

user_state.emotional_state: Ambivalent curiosity mixed with protective instinct. The host is drawn by the possibility of income (pleasure principle) but guarded about what they might have to surrender (instinctual freedom over their space). Freud Ch III: 'we prefer not to regard [the social source of suffering] as one at all' — hosts in discovery are not yet framing this as a social commitment, only as a financial opportunity.
user_state.knowledge_level: Minimal platform knowledge. May have heard about Split Lease from a referral, ad, or search. Knows they have a space and might want income from it. Does not yet understand the marketplace's rules, the vetting process, or the extent of commitment required.
user_state.commitment_level: Browsing. No commitment has been made. The host is in Freud's pre-civilized state — still autonomous, still in full control of their space. They have not yet submitted to any marketplace constraint.
user_state.data_available: Almost none. The platform may have referral source, landing page visit data, or ad click attribution. No profile, no property details, no stated intent.

reasons: The platform asks for information before demonstrating value (violates 'value before the ask' principle from user stories)
The host senses the magnitude of instinctual renunciation required (sharing their home) and is not yet convinced the reward justifies the sacrifice

Freud's hostility to civilization: a 'profound long-standing discontent' with systems that demand conformity — hosts who have had bad experiences with Craigslist, Airbnb, or roommate apps carry this civilizational resentment
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.' Freud Ch III: 'our so-called civilization itself is to blame for a great part of our misery, and we should be much happier if we were to give it up and go back to primitive conditions' — this maps directly to hosts who think 'I could just find someone on my own without dealing with a platform.'

key_quotes.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
key_quotes.relevance: Directly addresses why discovery has high dropout: demanding instinctual sacrifice (information, commitment) before demonstrating civilizational benefit (value, matches, income) triggers the pleasure principle violation that Freud describes.

key_quotes.quote: Our so-called civilization itself is to blame for a great part of our misery, and we should be much happier if we were to give it up and go back to primitive conditions.
key_quotes.relevance: This is the unconscious calculus in discovery: the host wonders whether the marketplace (civilization) will create more suffering than the independence (primitive conditions) of managing their space alone.

evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: Evaluation is the phase where the host begins to weigh the cost of instinctual renunciation against the promised benefits of marketplace participation. Freud Ch III frames this as the fundamental economic problem of the libido: 'happiness is something essentially subjective' and the host must calculate whether the pleasure gained (income, guaranteed payments, vetted guests) outweighs the suffering incurred (loss of privacy, stranger in the home, platform rules). The user stories analysis highlights two critical evaluation signals: 'Verified reviews and host credibility signals activate guests' and 'Messaging before proposals is a natural step.' Inverted for the host perspective, this means the host is evaluating whether the platform provides sufficient structure to make the civilizing sacrifice safe. Freud's insight that 'civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security' is the exact transaction the host is evaluating: will Split Lease provide enough security to justify surrendering control? The cross-activation framework from the user stories ('an experienced guest applying to a new host is cross-activation in action') reveals that evaluation is not just host-to-platform but host-to-marketplace: the host needs evidence that the other participants in this civilization are trustworthy.

user_state.emotional_state: Calculating anxiety. The host is performing a cost-benefit analysis that is partly rational (income vs. hassle) and partly unconscious (instinct vs. civilization). Freud Ch V: 'men clearly do not find it easy to do without satisfaction of this tendency' — the host does not want to surrender control and is looking for reasons not to.
user_state.knowledge_level: Emerging. The host is actively comparing Split Lease to alternatives (Craigslist, Airbnb, roommate apps). They may have had an initial call with an agent. They understand the basic proposition but not the details of payment guarantees, vetting processes, or dispute resolution.
user_state.commitment_level: Evaluating. The host has moved from browsing to active comparison. They are considering the platform but have not yet submitted to its requirements. This is Freud's moment of 'choosing civilization' — still reversible.
user_state.data_available: Referral source, landing page behavior, possibly an initial call transcript, comparison behavior (which pages visited, how long spent on guarantees/pricing pages).

reasons: The comparison to 'primitive conditions' (Craigslist, word of mouth) may feel favorable: less structure, less surrender, more personal control
Freud's 'narcissism of minor differences' applies: hosts focus on small shortcomings in the platform rather than large benefits, because the differences feel threatening to their autonomy

The user stories document identifies that 'Rod isn't sure people are willing to give all that information before they've seen any results' — evaluation fails when the platform demands too much before proving its civilizational value
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories, 'Probably Not True' section: 'Rod isn't sure people are willing to give all that information before they've seen any results. The platform needs to earn that trust first — show them something, then invite them to refine.' Freud Ch V: 'the liberty of the individual is not a benefit of culture. It was greatest before any culture' — hosts in evaluation are acutely aware they are being asked to trade liberty for structure.

key_quotes.quote: A skeptical guest who sees verified reviews, ID checks, and real host history doesn't need the platform to convince them — another user already did. Every review is a past guest activating a future one. The trust infrastructure is cross-activation infrastructure.
key_quotes.relevance: Inverted for hosts: a skeptical host who sees verified guest profiles, completed leases, and host success stories does not need the platform to convince them — another host already did. This is Freud's 'civilization binding members through identification': trust built by prior participants reduces the new participant's sense of instinctual sacrifice.

key_quotes.quote: If civilization requires such sacrifices, not only of sexuality but also of the aggressive tendencies in mankind, we can better understand why it should be so hard for men to feel happy in it... Civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security.
key_quotes.relevance: This is the exact transaction of evaluation: the host is deciding whether to exchange happiness (autonomy over their space) for security (guaranteed income, vetted guests). The platform must make the security tangible enough to justify the sacrifice.

onboarding.what_this_lens_reveals: Onboarding is the first act of civilizational submission: the host signs up, verifies identity, and connects with an assigned agent. Freud Ch III describes how 'the members of the community have restricted their possibilities of gratification, whereas the individual recognized no such restrictions' — onboarding is the moment of first restriction. The host is creating an account (submitting identity to the system), accepting terms (agreeing to platform rules), and entering personal information (surrendering privacy). The user stories document's principle that 'authentication should be invisible until it matters' is a direct Freudian insight: the civilizational demand should be hidden until the host is already engaged enough that the cost of withdrawal exceeds the cost of compliance. The journey map shows onboarding involves a 'first call' with the agent — this is Freud's mediating mechanism: civilization uses human identification (the agent as a relatable figure) to ease the pain of instinctual renunciation. The existing library (works-004, Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust) addresses this handoff, but the Freud lens adds: the agent is not just bridging trust, they are performing the role of the 'leader' who makes civilizational sacrifice tolerable through personal identification.

user_state.emotional_state: Tentative compliance. The host has decided to try but has not fully committed. Freud Ch III: 'order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done' — the host is entering the platform's order system and feeling the first constraints on their freedom. The agent relationship provides emotional reassurance.
user_state.knowledge_level: Growing but uneven. The host understands the value proposition from the evaluation phase. They are now learning the platform mechanics: how accounts work, what verification requires, what the agent relationship entails. They do not yet understand the full scope of what listing creation will demand.
user_state.commitment_level: Low-to-medium. They have created an account (sunk cost) and spoken with an agent (personal connection), but have not yet invested significant effort. Withdrawal is still easy and psychologically cheap.
user_state.data_available: Account creation data, identity verification status, agent assignment, call scheduling/completion, initial property information shared verbally during the call.

reasons: The gap between the human warmth of the agent call and the impersonal mechanics of the platform triggers what Freud calls the 'disappointment' of civilization: 'all this newly won power... has not increased the amount of pleasure they can obtain in life'
Identity verification feels like surveillance rather than safety — Freud's 'cultural privation' applied to personal data
If the platform demands too much information at once, it violates the 'invisible until it matters' principle and triggers premature resistance
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Authentication should be invisible until it matters. Inline auth pop-up, not a full-page redirect. Users don't lose search context. High-intent actions trigger it — nothing else.' Freud Ch III: the 'element of disappointment' — 'Mankind is proud of its exploits and has a right to be. But men are beginning to perceive that all this newly won power... has not made them feel any happier.' After the warm agent call, the platform's cold mechanics produce this disappointment.

key_quotes.quote: Authentication should be invisible until it matters. Inline auth pop-up, not a full-page redirect. Users don't lose search context.
key_quotes.relevance: Civilizational demands (identity verification, account creation) must be invisible until the host is already psychologically committed. Freud would say: minimize the felt cost of instinctual renunciation at the moment of entry.

key_quotes.quote: Human life in communities only becomes possible when a number of men unite together in strength superior to any single individual and remain united against all single individuals. The strength of this united body is then opposed as 'Right' against the strength of any individual... The members of the community have restricted their possibilities of gratification, whereas the individual recognized no such restrictions.
key_quotes.relevance: Onboarding is the moment the host joins the community and accepts its 'Right' over individual freedom. The platform's rules replace the host's personal autonomy over their space. This is the foundational civilizational act.

listing_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: Listing creation is the highest-intensity act of instinctual renunciation in the host journey. The host is not just filling out a form — they are codifying their private space into a public marketplace artifact. Photos of their home, descriptions of their rooms, disclosure of amenities, setting of rules — each step converts something intimate and personal into something standardized and transactable. Freud Ch III notes that civilization demands 'beauty, cleanliness and order' — the listing wizard is literally demanding these: beautiful photos, clean descriptions, ordered specifications. The user stories document identifies two critical mechanisms: 'Completion percentage is a good host nudge' and 'Pause matters more than delete.' The completion percentage is Freud's 'repetition-compulsion of order' applied as motivation — it quantifies how much of the civilizing process remains. Pause vs. delete is the Freudian insight about reversibility: a host who can pause (temporarily retreat from civilization) will tolerate more renunciation than one who faces only the binary of full compliance or total loss. The 6-step wizard in the journey map (Space Snapshot, Features, Lease Styles, Pricing, Rules, Photos) represents a graduated sequence of increasingly intimate disclosures. The existing library element works-002 (Design for the Depleted User) addresses cognitive load; the Freud lens adds that depletion here is not just cognitive but psychological — each step demands a deeper surrender of the host's private domain.

user_state.emotional_state: Ambivalent effort. The host is engaged but experiences each step as a new demand on their autonomy. Freud Ch III: 'human beings manifest an inborn tendency to negligence, irregularity and untrustworthiness in their work, and have to be laboriously trained to imitate the example of their celestial models.' The host wants to do a good job (the listing is for their own benefit) but resists the discipline the wizard imposes. The completion percentage serves as both motivator and anxiety trigger.
user_state.knowledge_level: Task-specific. The host knows their own space well but must translate that knowledge into the platform's categories. The user stories note that 'upfront information ask — users probably want to see something first' — hosts know what they have but resist the effort of encoding it in unfamiliar formats.
user_state.commitment_level: Medium-to-high. Significant effort has been invested. Cognitive sunk cost increases with each completed step. But incomplete listings represent the largest single pool of host dropout — the 6-step wizard is where the renunciation cost peaks.
user_state.data_available: Partial listing data (whatever steps are completed), time spent per step, abandonment point within the wizard, whether templates/common features were used (indicating desire for shortcuts past the renunciation).

reasons: The 6-step wizard demands sustained instinctual renunciation: each step makes the private more public
Photos are the most intimate disclosure — converting visual privacy into a public commodity. Many hosts stall here
Freud's 'cultural privation dominates the whole field of social relations' — the wizard IS the mechanism of cultural privation, and the host feels every step of it
Without pause functionality, an interrupted host faces total loss of their compliance investment
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Completion percentage is a good host nudge. Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live. A visible progress indicator creates just enough friction to get them to finish — without being in the way.' AND 'Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it. Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.' Freud Ch III: 'it is impossible to ignore the extent to which civilization is built up on renunciation of instinctual gratifications' — the wizard is the concrete mechanism of this renunciation.

key_quotes.quote: Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live. A visible progress indicator on the listing card creates just enough friction to get them to finish — without being in the way.
key_quotes.relevance: The completion percentage is a civilizing mechanism: it makes the host's partial compliance visible and creates social pressure (even self-directed) to complete the instinctual sacrifice.

key_quotes.quote: Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it. Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.
key_quotes.relevance: Freud's insight that civilization must allow temporary retreats from renunciation: the host who can pause is not abandoning civilization, only resting from it. The one who can only delete is forced into a binary (full compliance or full loss) that triggers the 'revolt against civilization' Freud describes.

key_quotes.quote: It is impossible to ignore the extent to which civilization is built up on renunciation of instinctual gratifications... This 'cultural privation' dominates the whole field of social relations between human beings; we know already that it is the cause of the antagonism against which all civilization has to fight.
key_quotes.relevance: The listing wizard is the platform's most concentrated form of cultural privation: the host must surrender privacy (photos), autonomy (rules they must declare), and intimacy (descriptions of their personal space). Every incomplete wizard is evidence of the antagonism Freud predicts.

pricing.what_this_lens_reveals: Pricing is where the host must translate the emotional value of their space into the marketplace's economic language. Freud Ch III observes that 'the force behind all human activities is a striving towards the two convergent aims of profit and pleasure' — pricing is the phase where these two aims collide directly. The host's instinctual valuation of their space (what it means to them, what it cost them, what it represents) must be compressed into a nightly rate. The journey map shows pricing as Step 4 of the wizard, with 'default values already populated.' The user stories analysis does not address pricing directly, which is itself a signal: pricing is so loaded with instinctual anxiety that even the analysis avoids it. Freud's framework explains why: setting a price on one's private space is a form of sublimation — the instinct to protect and hoard the space must be transformed into an economic transaction. Smart defaults (from the existing library, works-002) serve as the platform's civilizational guidance: they tell the host 'this is what the civilization considers fair' without requiring the host to perform the painful calculation themselves. The platform is doing the sublimation work on the host's behalf.

user_state.emotional_state: Defensive calculation. The host wants to maximize return (pleasure principle) but fears underselling their space (instinctual loss) or overpricing and getting no guests (civilizational failure). Freud Ch III: 'happiness is something essentially subjective' — the 'right' price is the one that satisfies the host's subjective sense of fair exchange for their instinctual sacrifice, not necessarily the market-optimal price.
user_state.knowledge_level: Variable. Some hosts have researched comparable listings; others have no frame of reference. The host knows what they pay in mortgage/rent but may not know how to translate that into a nightly rate. The fee structure (Split Lease's cut) may be unclear.
user_state.commitment_level: High. The host is deep into the wizard (Step 4 of 6). Significant sunk cost. But pricing is an emotional bottleneck — a host who cannot resolve the price anxiety may abandon even with 3 prior steps completed.
user_state.data_available: Property details (from prior wizard steps), local market comps (if the platform provides them), the host's stated or implied financial expectations from the agent call.

reasons: Pricing anxiety: the host fears both underselling (instinctual loss) and overpricing (marketplace rejection)
Fee structure opacity: if the platform's cut is not clearly explained, the host feels an additional layer of civilizational extraction — Freud's 'privation' compounded
Comparison to 'primitive conditions': the host may think 'if I found someone on Craigslist, I'd keep all the money' — the marketplace fee is felt as a tax on participation in civilization
dropout_risk.evidence: Journey map: 'The pricing section appears with default values already populated. The Host reviews and accepts the defaults.' The fact that defaults exist and are accepted suggests most hosts do NOT want to deliberate on pricing — they want the civilization to decide for them. Freud Ch V: 'the inertia of libido, its disinclination to relinquish an old position in favour of a new one' — the host's instinctual price ('my space is worth X') resists the marketplace's price ('the market says Y').

key_quotes.quote: The pricing section appears with default values already populated. The Host reviews and accepts the defaults, clicking 'Next' to continue.
key_quotes.relevance: The defaults are the platform performing sublimation on the host's behalf: converting instinctual attachment to the space into an economically viable rate. Most hosts accept this civilizational guidance rather than performing the painful calculation themselves.

key_quotes.quote: If we assume as a general hypothesis that the force behind all human activities is a striving towards the two convergent aims of profit and pleasure, we must then acknowledge this as valid also for these other manifestations of culture.
key_quotes.relevance: Pricing is where profit and pleasure converge most visibly. The host wants both maximum income (profit) and a price that honors the emotional value of their space (pleasure). The platform must help reconcile these convergent aims.

proposal_mgmt.what_this_lens_reveals: Proposal management is the phase where the host confronts the reality of another person — a stranger — seeking to enter their space. Freud Ch V states: 'men are not gentle, friendly creatures wishing for love, who simply defend themselves if they are attacked, but that a powerful measure of desire for aggression has to be reckoned as part of their instinctual endowment.' This is the deep anxiety beneath every proposal review: the host must evaluate whether this stranger will respect their space or violate it. The user stories document identifies that 'the proposal itself is a cross-activation event' and that 'a well-structured proposal activates the host to respond.' Freud explains the mechanism: a structured proposal reduces the perceived aggression potential of the stranger by demonstrating civilized behavior (clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent). The guest who submits a well-formed proposal is performing civilizational compliance, which signals to the host that this person has already submitted to the same renunciations the host has accepted. The journey map shows the host can counter-propose (changing duration from 16 to 10 weeks) — this is the host exercising what remains of their instinctual freedom within the civilizational framework. The counter-proposal is a controlled assertion of autonomy: 'I accept this stranger, but on my terms.' Freud Ch III calls this the essential negotiation: 'finding some expedient (i.e. satisfying) solution between these individual claims and those of the civilized community.'

user_state.emotional_state: Vigilant gatekeeping. The host is protective of their space (instinct) while recognizing the financial benefit of accepting a guest (civilizational reward). Freud Ch V: 'their neighbour is to them not only a possible helper or sexual object, but also a temptation to them to gratify their aggressiveness on him' — the host fears the reverse: that the guest will exploit, damage, or disrespect their space. Urgency surfaces here: 'Urgency should surface first on the dashboard' (user stories) reflects the host's need for control over the pace of engagement.
user_state.knowledge_level: Good platform knowledge but limited guest knowledge. The host understands how proposals work but knows little about the specific guest. The platform's vetting and credibility signals (reviews, ID checks) become the civilizational guarantee that makes acceptance psychologically safe.
user_state.commitment_level: High. The host has a live listing and is receiving proposals. Sunk cost is substantial. But each individual proposal is a new decision point with its own acceptance/rejection calculus.
user_state.data_available: Guest profile, proposal terms (dates, duration, pricing), guest history and reviews (if available), vetting/verification status, communication history.

reasons: Freud's 'primary hostility': the host's instinct distrusts strangers, and insufficient guest credibility information confirms the distrust
Proposal overload or neglect: if proposals arrive when the host is not ready, they may default to inaction (Freud's 'inertia of libido')
The counter-proposal mechanism may feel like negotiation fatigue — the host wants control but not endless back-and-forth
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Urgency should surface first on the dashboard. Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings — that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.' AND 'A well-structured proposal — clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent — activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction.' Freud Ch V: 'the existence of this tendency to aggression which we can detect in ourselves and rightly presume to be present in others is the factor that disturbs our relations with our neighbours' — every vague proposal triggers this presumption.

key_quotes.quote: A well-structured proposal — clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent — activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction. Stories that push toward more structured, pre-populated proposal forms aren't just about UX, they're about making the cross-activation moment as clean as possible.
key_quotes.relevance: The structured proposal is a civilizational artifact: it demonstrates that the guest has submitted to the same rules the host has accepted. A vague proposal is uncivilized — it signals that the stranger has not yet renounced their instinctual chaos for marketplace order.

key_quotes.quote: The bit of truth behind all this — one so eagerly denied — is that men are not gentle, friendly creatures wishing for love... but that a powerful measure of desire for aggression has to be reckoned as part of their instinctual endowment. The result is that their neighbour is to them not only a possible helper or sexual object, but also a temptation to them to gratify their aggressiveness on him.
key_quotes.relevance: This is the unconscious calculus behind every proposal review. The host is not just evaluating dates and pricing — they are assessing whether this stranger will be a 'possible helper' (good guest) or a threat (someone who will damage their space, violate their rules, or exploit the arrangement).

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: Active lease is the phase of sustained civilizational coexistence. The stranger is now in the host's space. Freud Ch V describes how 'civilization is perpetually menaced with disintegration through this primary hostility of men towards one another' — the active lease period is the ongoing test of whether the civilizational structure (the lease agreement, the platform's rules, the Stays Manager) can contain the instinctual tensions between two people sharing a space. The journey map details the mechanisms of civilized coexistence: Stays Manager (date changes), cleaning photos, reviews, the House Manual. Each is a civilizational tool — a way to channel potential conflict into structured interaction. The user stories analysis does not directly address active lease mechanics but its core messaging insight applies: 'Messaging before proposals is a natural step... the park analogy holds — you check availability before committing.' During active lease, the park analogy extends to every micro-interaction: the guest notifies arrival before appearing, sends cleaning photos before departing. These are civilizational rituals — structured behaviors that reduce the host's instinctual anxiety about the stranger in their space. The existing library has strong active_lease coverage (152 mentions), but the Freud lens adds the interpretive framework: these mechanisms work because they satisfy the host's need for 'order' — Freud's 'repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.'

user_state.emotional_state: Oscillating between comfort and vigilance. When the guest follows the rituals (cleaning photos, arrival notifications, respectful communication), the host experiences civilizational satisfaction — the system works. When rituals are broken (missed communication, messy space, unexpected guests), the host's instinctual hostility resurfaces. Freud Ch III: 'the benefits of order are incontestable: it enables us to use space and time to the best advantage, while saving expenditure of mental energy.'
user_state.knowledge_level: High. The host understands the platform, the lease terms, and the guest's patterns. Knowledge gaps are guest-specific: how reliable is this person? Are they following the rules? The review system provides civilizational feedback.
user_state.commitment_level: Very high. The lease is active, payments are flowing, the guest is physically present. This is full civilizational participation. Withdrawal means breaking the lease — a major disruptive event.
user_state.data_available: Payment history, stay dates, date change requests, communication logs, cleaning photos, reviews given and received, House Manual access patterns, any reported issues.

reasons: The lease is binding — civilizational structure enforces participation
Payment flow provides ongoing instinctual reward (the profit that justified the sacrifice)
The guest is physically present, making 'dropping out' a complex real-world action, not a digital one
dropout_risk.evidence: Journey map: 'Date change requests follow the same confirmation flow and may require the other party's approval depending on the lease terms.' The confirmation flow is Freud's 'law' — 'the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.' Both host and guest operate under shared rules, which provides the security that Freud identifies as civilization's primary offering. Freud Ch V: 'civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security' — the active lease is where that security is delivered.

key_quotes.quote: Reviews are submitted after each individual stay (not just at lease end), building a track record over time.
key_quotes.relevance: Per-stay reviews are a civilizational monitoring mechanism: they impose accountability at every repetition of the coexistence cycle. Freud's 'order is a kind of repetition-compulsion' — the review cycle creates predictable moments of civilizational assessment that reduce the host's instinctual anxiety about the ongoing arrangement.

key_quotes.quote: Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided. The benefits of order are incontestable: it enables us to use space and time to the best advantage, while saving expenditure of mental energy.
key_quotes.relevance: The active lease's mechanisms — Stays Manager, date change tool, arrival notifications, cleaning photos — are all forms of Freudian order: repetition-compulsions that reduce doubt and hesitation. They convert potentially anxiety-laden encounters into predictable, manageable rituals.

retention.what_this_lens_reveals: Retention is the phase where the host decides whether to re-enter civilization or return to 'primitive conditions.' Freud Ch III frames this as the recurring question: 'we should be much happier if we were to give it up and go back to primitive conditions.' A host whose lease has ended stands at this exact fork: re-list (accept another round of instinctual renunciation for civilizational rewards) or withdraw (reclaim full autonomy over their space). The user stories document's insight about Pause vs. Delete maps directly: 'Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing' — for retention, the equivalent is making re-entry effortless. A host who must rebuild their listing from scratch faces the full renunciation cost again, which Freud would predict deters return. A host who can reactivate an existing listing faces only the marginal cost of accepting a new stranger. Freud Ch V introduces 'the narcissism of minor differences' — a concept that illuminates retention failure: hosts who leave do not necessarily leave because of a major grievance but because of accumulated small irritations that crystallize into a narrative of civilizational dissatisfaction. The existing library has the weakest coverage here (44 mentions), making retention a significant gap. The Freud lens reveals why: retention is not about features or UX — it is about the host's deep psychological calculation of whether civilizational participation was worth the instinctual cost. This calculation happens outside the platform, in the host's subjective experience of the entire journey.

user_state.emotional_state: Retrospective weighing. The host is evaluating the entire experience: was the income worth the sacrifice of privacy? Was the guest tolerable? Did the platform protect them? Freud Ch III: 'happiness is something essentially subjective' — a host who earned $5,000 but felt their privacy was violated is unhappy; a host who earned $2,000 but felt respected is satisfied. The subjective experience of civilizational participation determines retention, not the objective outcome.
user_state.knowledge_level: Complete. The host has lived through the entire cycle. They know the platform, the process, the guest interaction patterns, and the emotional cost of participation. There is nothing new to learn — only a decision to make.
user_state.commitment_level: Zero to high — entirely dependent on their retrospective assessment. A satisfied host may re-list immediately. A dissatisfied host may never return. There is no structural commitment holding them.
user_state.data_available: Complete journey data: listing performance, guest reviews, payment history, communication logs, date change frequency, dispute history, time between lease end and next listing (if any), referral behavior.

reasons: The instinctual cost of hosting is felt most acutely in retrospect — Freud's 'narcissism of minor differences' means small grievances accumulate into a narrative of civilizational dissatisfaction
No structural mechanism compels re-listing: the host must voluntarily choose to surrender autonomy again
Comparison to 'not hosting' (primitive conditions of full privacy) feels appealing after a period of sustained renunciation
If the platform did not adequately mediate the host-guest relationship, the host concludes that civilization failed to provide the promised security
dropout_risk.evidence: User stories: 'Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it. Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.' This applies directly to retention: a host who paused is psychologically closer to re-entry than one who deleted. Freud Ch V: 'It is always possible to unite considerable numbers of men in love towards one another, so long as there are still some remaining as objects for aggressive manifestations' — a host community (referral programs, host forums, shared identity) could channel the aggressive residue of the hosting experience into outgroup comparison rather than platform rejection.

key_quotes.quote: Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.
key_quotes.relevance: For retention, the ability to pause and return without rebuilding is the platform equivalent of Freud's 'security': the host knows their civilizational investment is preserved and can be reactivated with minimal additional renunciation cost.

key_quotes.quote: There is an advantage, not to be undervalued, in the existence of smaller communities, through which the aggressive instinct can find an outlet in enmity towards those outside the group. It is always possible to unite considerable numbers of men in love towards one another, so long as there are still some remaining as objects for aggressive manifestations.
key_quotes.relevance: A host community — forums, referral networks, shared identity as 'Split Lease hosts' — creates the smaller community Freud describes. Hosts united by shared experience can direct their civilizational frustrations outward (toward competitors, toward bad guests as a category) rather than inward (toward the platform itself). This is the psychological infrastructure of retention.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The Renunciation Gradient — each phase demands a deeper surrender of instinctual freedom, with listing_creation as the peak and active_lease as the plateau
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Freud Ch III: 'it is impossible to ignore the extent to which civilization is built up on renunciation of instinctual gratifications.' The host journey follows a predictable gradient: discovery (no renunciation), evaluation (considering renunciation), onboarding (first renunciation — identity), listing_creation (peak renunciation — converting private space to public artifact), pricing (sublimating emotional attachment into economic value), proposal_mgmt (accepting a stranger), active_lease (sustained coexistence), retention (deciding whether to repeat the cycle). The user stories document's 'value before the ask' principle is the design response: at each step of the gradient, value must precede or accompany the demanded renunciation.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Civilizational Mediation — the platform serves as the 'law' that makes host-guest coexistence possible by constraining both parties equally
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Freud Ch III: 'the first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice — that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.' The journey map shows this at every interaction: confirmation dialogs ('Yes, Proceed'), the counter-proposal mechanism, the date change approval flow, per-stay reviews. Each is a mechanism of 'justice' — ensuring neither host nor guest can unilaterally violate the shared agreement. The user stories document's emphasis on structured proposals and pre-populated forms extends this: even the proposal format enforces civilizational standards on the guest, which protects the host. When this mediation fails (disputes, unresponsive guests, broken rules), the host experiences Freud's 'disappointment of civilization' and is more likely to exit at retention.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Cross-Activation as Civilizational Binding — trust between marketplace participants reduces the felt cost of instinctual sacrifice
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: User stories: 'When someone who's already used Split Lease applies to a host who's never had a guest, that guest's reputation does the selling.' Freud Ch V: civilization 'makes use of every means and favours every avenue by which powerful identifications can be created among them, and exacts a heavy toll of aim-inhibited libido in order to strengthen communities by bonds of friendship between the members.' The platform's review system, verified profiles, and guest history are mechanisms of identification: they allow the host to see the guest not as a threatening stranger but as a fellow participant in the civilizational order. Each positive review is evidence that the civilization works — that the renunciation is worthwhile.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The Pause Principle — reversibility reduces civilizational resistance at every phase
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: User stories: 'Pause matters more than delete. Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it.' Freud Ch III: 'the desire for freedom that makes itself felt in a human community may be a revolt against some existing injustice and so may prove favourable to a further development of civilization and remain compatible with it. But it may also have its origin in the primitive roots of the personality, still unfettered by civilizing influences.' Pause accommodates both types of freedom desire: the host who pauses due to a specific grievance (civilized revolt) and the host who pauses due to instinctual need for autonomy (primitive roots). In both cases, preserving the option to return — without the full cost of re-creation — keeps the host within the civilizational orbit. Delete is the platform forcing a binary that Freud would predict drives permanent exit.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Order as Anxiety Reduction — repetitive structures and rituals across phases reduce the instinctual threat of the unknown
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Freud Ch III: 'Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.' Journey map: the confirmation dialog ('Yes, Proceed') appears at every critical action. The listing wizard follows a predictable sequence. The Stays Manager creates a weekly rhythm of arrival, stay, cleaning photos, review. User stories: 'Urgency should surface first on the dashboard' — predictable dashboard structure is another form of Freudian order that reduces anxiety. When the platform introduces novelty or unpredictability (new UI patterns, unexpected notifications, format changes), it disrupts the order that the host depends on for psychological safety.

sources_consulted: user-stories-initial-analysis.md — Rod's analysis of user stories with definitive truths, probable non-truths, and cross-activation potential. Used for host-side UX principles (value before ask, authentication invisibility, completion percentage, pause vs delete, urgency surfacing, messaging as cross-activation, structured proposals). Document focuses primarily on guest UX but was inverted for host perspective throughout.

freud-civilization-discontents-ch3-ch5.txt — Chapters III and V of Freud's Civilization and Its Discontents. Ch III: three sources of suffering (nature, body, human relationships), hostility to civilization, pleasure principle, order/beauty/cleanliness as cultural demands, sublimation, instinctual renunciation as civilization's foundation. Ch V: civilization vs individual instinct, aggression as innate, 'narcissism of minor differences,' civilizational binding through identification, the exchange of happiness for security. Applied throughout as the interpretive framework for why hosts resist, where anxiety peaks, and how the platform mediates between individual desire and social obligation.

split-lease-journey-map.md — Complete host and guest journey map covering 5 phases: listing creation (6-step wizard), guest proposal, host counter-proposal, guest acceptance, post-acceptance (documents, leases, Stays Manager, reviews, House Manual, communication). Used for concrete journey mechanics and touchpoint identification.

library/elements.json (first 200 lines) — Existing element library. Reviewed works-001 (System 1 Trust Gate), works-002 (Depleted User), works-003 (Cognitive Speed Matching), works-004 (Human-to-Digital Trust Bridge). Noted phase coverage: active_lease strongest (152 mentions), discovery (63), pricing (51), retention weakest (44). This run's Freud lens adds strongest value to retention (psychological framework for re-engagement), listing_creation (instinctual renunciation gradient), and discovery (civilizational resistance at first contact).
